I.1.</br>From the morning grey and still</br>Fast the dews of night retire;</br>Wide along the heathy hill,</br>Burns a blazing Stream of fire;</br>Dark before the glittering gleam,</br>Shadows black of horsemen dance;</br>A steely light with starry beam,</br>Glimmers from the shivering lance:</br>Down the mountain, grand and slow,</br>Processioning in state they go:</br>In a bright cloud they close their firm array;</br>Throbbings of glory from the clarions sound;</br>Before them rolls the thunder of their way;</br>Before them darkness sweeps the shaking ground;</br>Heard ye the shout, that rent the air?</br>Saw ye the brandish'd spear, and flash of fiery glare?

I.2.</br>Like the wood's edge at deep of night</br>Striking back the heedless eye;</br>Gazing for the coming fight;</br>Dark and terrible we lie;</br>Silence dread and whispers low,</br>Panting expectation show;</br>With outstretch'd arms and streaming eyes</br>Thus the impassion'd father cries;</br>"Flower of hope, of fragrance wide,</br>Gem, that deck'd the green bank's swell,</br>No more upon thy painted pride,</br>My gazing tenderness will dwell.</br>Lightnings of Fury through my eyeballs dart</br>The worm of shame sleeps not, that twines around my heart."

I.3.</br>"Maiden of the shining eyes,</br>Cava dear and Cava fair,</br>Starting tears, and stealing sighs,</br>Would a father's pride declare;</br>Sweet the summer breeze, that blows</br>Lightly from the dancing rose;</br>Soft the silver glitter shed</br>From the violet's weeping head;</br>Gay the bird's new-feather'd wing.</br>Gay the fresh-born leaf of spring:</br>So sweet, so soft, so gay,</br>The meeken'd lustre of her vernal day;</br>When in the dance her graceful way she moved,</br>In speechless agonies of bliss I loved;</br>The flushes of her beauty sunk my eyes,</br>To thoughtless vacancy, and melting soft surprize."

II.1.</br>See the wind (the day is still)</br>The poplar's twinkling verdure shed;</br>Ah!  the judgment from the hill</br>Shows through the cloud his awful head!</br>Speedy death and present fear,</br>Guilty King, there vow to thee</br>Men, that never shed a tear,</br>Stormy or sullen as the sea;</br>Does the robber ever laugh?</br>Does the wolf's eye lose its fire?</br>These the bleeding life that quaff,</br>No human sympathies inspire:</br>Revenge, that shows what man can do,</br>Unfurl our banners thus, and terrify his view.

II.2.</br>Now the mountain's steep beneath,</br>The winter's flood has found its shores;</br>Now the north wind sweeps the heath</br>On our driving battle pours;</br>O'er the billows of the war,</br>Rodorigo shines afar;</br>The Northern Boar, with ruffian sway,</br>That bore the Eagle's spoil away;</br>Alarick's tremendous name</br>Burn his cheek with rage and shame;</br>Seven nights, asleep, awake,</br>Fast the bubbles rise and break;</br>Mighty warrior, mighty lord!</br>Will not greatness ease afford?</br>Round him teazing visions fly,</br>Suspense's shifting form and writhing agony.

II.3.</br>Seven nights and seven days</br>Will he gain a hero's praise—</br>Wide the doors enchanted throw</br>Blast his soul's desire and show!</br>King, those swarthy warriors see</br>Foes, that will thy victors be;</br>Read the characters of fate</br>They proclaim thy kingdom's date;</br>Urging is the unseen pow'r,</br>End of doubt and end of strife;</br>Soon will come the fatal hour,</br>Last of war, and last of life;</br>Vain the ardour, vain the toil,</br>Thine is not the joy of spoil;</br>Stony horror fills thine eyes;</br>Trumpets of Glory sound, and swell him till he dies.

III.1.</br>Live, Hope; prediction is but vain;</br>Mists gather to dispense again;</br>Does the thunder rend the skies?</br>In innoxious tears it dies—</br>Ah!  who is that, in deep despair,</br>Retiring with the lion's shame,</br>The fury of his glowing air,</br>A fire's expiring flash of flame;</br>By Fate's unmoving gaze downcast,</br>Weary, mad, forlorn, and last:</br>Flown are his bands; alone remain</br>Drops of the tempest's ceasing rain;</br>"Low the gasping Hero lies,"</br>(Hear the exulting Father's yell)</br>"Gambol," he screams, "ye fiends, before his eyes,</br>And greet his harrow'd ears with howls of Hell.

III.2.</br>"Is he gone, the Lord of Light,</br>The Sun, that spread his beams so wide?</br>Woe to Spain and endless night!</br>Shone he high in noon of pride?</br>No, it was with a glimmering flame,</br>The mockery of a winter's morn;</br>Where is the odour of his fame?</br>Gone with the fleeting flow'r, for ever, ever gone."

III.  3.</br>Julian, hear my dying breath;</br>(Prophetic is the voice of death;)</br>Think'st thou that belongs to thee,</br>The mighty of the mightiest decree?</br>He grants the infidel an hour</br>To punish Vice's lawless power;</br>Why pass those sages o'er the vale?</br>All hail, ye unborn nations, hail,</br>With beaming eyes of brighter rays!</br>Turn, instrument of Heaven, and gaze—</br>Ah!  famish'd in a dungeon deep,</br>At the bright day does Julian weep?</br>Dead do thy wife, thy children, lie?</br>Liv'd they with wishes but to die?</br>Blest is Roderick that's gone—</br>Forget not in thy woes this parting smile of scorn.</br>
